p: The effects of opioid abuse on the central nervous system (CNS) have been extensively examined. Immediate effects of opioids result in decreased levels of consciousness, sedation (Collett 1998; Thompson 2000; Indelicato and Portenoy 2002), drowsiness, and sleep disturbances (Moore and Dimsdale 2002; Bourne and Mills 2004; Qureshi and Lee-Chiong 2004). While acute opioid exposure can impair cognition in healthy subjects (Lawlor 2002; Ersek et al. 2004), enduring cognitive and psychomotor deficits occur with chronic opioid use (Sjogren et al. 2000; Dublin et al. 2015; Roberts et al. 2018; Wollman et al. 2019; Serafini et al. 2020), including altered pain perception (opioid-induced hyperalgesia), dysregulated reward/saliency processing, hyperkatifeia, and epigenetic changes, which can persist years following abstinence (Ersche et al. 2006; Browne et al. 2020). The behavioral changes seen with long-term opioid use are accompanied by lasting structural and epigenetic (e.g., altered DNA methylation and expression of non-coding RNAs) alterations in brain regions implicated in mood, reward, and motivation (Upadhyay et al. 2010; Dublin et al. 2015; Volkow and Morales 2015; Koob and Volkow 2016; Serafini et al. 2020).
